Net Change Theorem
Net change theorem
Net change
Checking a stock market investment every day can be stressful. The value might go up on Monday, drop on Tuesday, rise again on Wednesday, and fall on Thursday. The daily ups and downs can be overwhelming. But what really matters to an investor is simple. When it is time to sell, the investor wants to know if the investment gained or lost value relative to the purchase price. The investor is only interested in the net change, or overall change, in the value of the investment.
The
net change
in a function
F(x)
over an interval
[a, b]
is
F(b) - F(a).
Net change measures the overall gain or loss between the starting value
x = a
and the ending value
x = b.
This lesson will demonstrate how to find the net change of a function.

Lesson summary
Net change is the overall change in a function between
2
values.
The net change in
F
over the interval
[a, b]
is
F(b) - F(a)\text{.}
The Net Change Theorem
Given the function
F(x),
the net change of
F
on
[a, b]
is
F(b) - F(a)\text{.}
But sometimes we know the rate of change and we don't know the function. Ex: A car’s speedometer shows the car's speed. However, the speedometer does not directly give the change in the position of the car over a given time period.
Fortunately, we can still find the net change using the rate of change
F^\prime(x)\text{.}
The Fundamental Theorem of Calculus (Part II) gives the key relationship:
\displaystyle \int_a^b F^\prime(x) \, dx = F(b) - F(a)
To find the net change, integrate the rate of change over
[a, b]\text{.}
This lesson will explain how to use rates of change to find net change.
FOLLOW UP TEXT (NOT PART OF FRAMING TEXT)
To find the net change given the rate of change, we use the Net Change Theorem.
Net Change Theorem
If
F^\prime(x)
is the rate of change of
F(x)\text{,}
then the net change in
F
over
[a, b]
is
F(b) - F(a) = \displaystyle \int_a^b F^\prime(x) \, dx

Lesson summary
Integrate the rate of change of a function to find the net change.
Net Change Theorem: If
F^\prime(x)
is the rate of change of
F(x)\text{,}
then the net change in
F
over
[a, b]
is
F(b) - F(a) = \displaystyle \int_a^b F^\prime(x) \, dx\text{.}
The Net Change Theorem is a reorganization of the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus (Part II). Net change is so powerful in applications that the result is renamed to emphasize the theorem’s usefulness.
Velocity and displacement
Speed describes how fast an object moves. Velocity describes how fast and in which direction an object moves. Ex: A car travels east at
40\text{ mph }
for
3\text{ hours,}
then turns around and travels west at
40\text{ mph }
for
2\text{ hours.}
The speed of the car is always
40\text{ mph,}
but the velocity changes direction:
v(t) = \begin{cases} \, \, \, \, 40  \qquad 0 \leq t <3 \quad \text{ driving east} \\ -40 \qquad 3 < t \leq 5 \quad \text{ driving west} \end{cases}
If we integrate the velocity, we get the net change in position of the car. This net change is the displacement, or the distance between the car’s starting point and ending point. The direction of travel will affect the displacement.
This lesson explains how to integrate velocity to find displacement.

Integrating gives
\displaystyle \int_3^5 (-40) \, dt = \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}} \text{.}
Integrating gives
\displaystyle \int_3^5 (-40) \, dt = (-40t) {\large|}_3^5
Complete the integration by substituting the endpoints to get
(-40t) {\large|}_3^5 = (-40(5)) - (-40(3))
and simplifying.
Integrating and simplifying gives:
\begin{align*}
          \displaystyle \int_3^5 (-40) \, dt &= (-40t) {\large|}_3^5 \\
          &= (-40(5)) - (-40(3)) \\
          &= -200 + 120 \\
          &= -80
        \end{align*}

for
2\text{ hours.}
The car then turns around and travels south at

for

Find the car’s displacement at the end of the drive.
The car’s velocity at time
t
(in hours) can be described using the function
\underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}} \text{.}
v(t) = \begin{cases}  60 \qquad 0 \leq t <2 \quad \\ 40 \qquad 2 < t \leq 5 \quad \end{cases}
Velocity includes direction. The car changes direction after
2\text{ hours,}

Lesson summary
Speed describes how fast an object moves.
Velocity describes both how fast and in what direction an object moves.
The integral of velocity over
[a,b ] \text{,}
or
\displaystyle \int_a^b v(t) \, dt,
gives displacement, or net change in position,
s(b) - s(a) \text{.}
Displacement depends on the direction of motion.
Speed and total distance traveled
Unlike velocity, speed does not take the direction of motion into account. Speed only tells us how fast an object is moving. The previous lesson explained that integrating the velocity yields displacement.
Integrating the speed, or absolute value of velocity, will give the total distance traveled. The absolute value ensures that the direction of travel does not affect the total distance.
Ex: A car travels east at
40\text{ mph}
for
3\text{ hours,}
then turns around and travels west at
40\text{ mph}
for
2\text{ hours.}
While the velocity of the car changes signs, the speed of the car is a constant
40\text{ mph.}
Integrating the speed function over
[0, 5]
will give the total number of miles traveled by the car during the
5\text{-hour}
trip.
This lesson will demonstrate how to integrate speed to find the total distance traveled.
Todo

In this example, the total distance traveled is expected to be
\underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}}
the displacement.
more than
The total distance traveled adds all positive values. In displacement, distance traveled in the positive direction can cancel with distance traveled in the negative direction. So the total distance traveled is expected to be more than the displacement.
less than
The total distance traveled uses an absolute value. So the distance can never be less than the displacement, which can include both positive and negative terms.
equal to
If the car only drives in the positive direction, then the total distance traveled will be equal to the displacement. In this example, the car does travel for
2\text{ hours}
in the negative direction, so distance and displacement cannot be equal.

The total distance ignores direction. The displacement includes direction, so the displacement will be less than the total distance traveled.

60\text{ mph}
for
2\text{ hours,}

40\text{ mph}

3\text{ hours.}
Find the car’s total distance traveled at the end of the drive.
The car’s velocity at time
t
(in hours) is
v(t) = \begin{cases} \, \, \, \, 60 \qquad 0 \leq t <2 \quad \\ -40 \qquad 2 < t \leq 5 \quad \end{cases}
The car’s total distance traveled at the end of the
5\text{-hour}
drive can be found using
\underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}} \text{.}
\displaystyle \int_0^2 60 \ dt + \displaystyle \int_2^5 (-40) \ dt
The second integral,
\displaystyle \int_2^5 (-40) \ dt,
should not include a negative sign. The total distance traveled does not depend on direction. Distance traveled is the integral of speed, or the absolute value of velocity.
\displaystyle \int_0^2 60 \ dt + \displaystyle \int_2^5 40 \ dt
The total distance traveled does not depend on direction. Distance traveled is the integral of speed, or the absolute value of velocity, so the car’s distance traveled can be found using the integral
\begin{align*} \displaystyle \int_0^5 {\large|} v(t) {\large|} \, dt & =  \displaystyle \int_0^2 {\large|} 60 {\large|} \, dt + \displaystyle \int_2^5 {\large|} -40 {\large|} \, dt \\ & = \displaystyle \int_0^2 60 \, dt + \displaystyle \int_2^5 40 \, dt \end{align*}
\displaystyle \int_0^2 (-40) \ dt + \displaystyle \int_2^5 60 \ dt
This option indicates the car drives south at
40\text{ mph}
for
2\text{ hours}
and north at
60\text{ mph}
for
3\text{ hours.}
Instead, the car drives north at
60\text{ mph}
from
t = 0
to
t = 2,
then drives south at
40\text{ mph}
from
t =2
to
t = 5.
Also, total distance traveled ignores direction, so both integrals will not have a negative sign.
\displaystyle \int_0^2 40 \ dt + \displaystyle \int_2^5 60 \ dt
This option indicates the car drives at
40\text{ mph}
for
2\text{ hours}
and
60\text{ mph}
for
3\text{ hours.}
Instead, the car drives at
60\text{ mph}
for
2\text{ hours}
and
40\text{ mph}
for
3\text{ hours.}
The car’s total distance traveled at the end of the
5\text{-hour}
drive is
\displaystyle \int_0^2 60 \, dt + \displaystyle \int_2^5 40 \, dt  = 60t {\Large|}_0^2 + 40t {\Large|}_2^5
So the total distance is
\underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}} \text{.}
The car’s total distance traveled is
\begin{align*} \displaystyle \int_0^2 60 \, dt + \displaystyle \int_2^5 40 \, dt  & = 60t {\Large|}_0^2 + 40t {\Large|}_2^5 \\& = \left(60(2) - 60(0) \right) +  \left( 40(5) - (40)(2) \right) \\& = (120 - 0) + (200 - 80) \\& = 240 \text{ miles}\end{align*}
Speed is 60 from t = 0 to t = 2 and 40 from t = 2 to t = 5. Area under speed is 120 from t = 0 to t = 2 and 120 from t = 2 to t = 5.
Substitute
t = 0
and
t = 2
in
60t,
and
t = 2
and
t = 5
in
40t \text{.}
After substituting, the displacement is
\left(60(2) - 60(0) \right) +  \left( 40(5) - (40)(2) \right) \text{.}
Now simplify.
miles

Lesson summary
Speed describes how fast an object moves, while velocity describes both how fast and in what direction the object moves.
The integral of speed over
[a, b],
\displaystyle \int_a^b {\large|} v(t) {\large|} \, dt,
gives the total distance traveled.
The total distance does not depend on direction.
The total distance traveled will always be greater than or equal to the displacement and will always be nonnegative.
Net change and area or volume problems
Sometimes measuring how fast an area or volume is changing is easier than measuring the area or volume.
Ex: A faucet is turned on, and water begins flowing out of a hot water heater. A flow meter can measure how quickly the water is flowing out of the tank, or the rate of change of the volume,
V^\prime(t) \text{.}
The water tank is not transparent, so we cannot measure the volume
V(t)
of water left in the tank directly.
One way to determine the change in volume of water in the tank is to integrate the rate of change. This lesson will explain how to use the Net Change Theorem for area and volume problems.
Todo

The net change in
V
over the first
5\text{ hours}
is expected to be
\underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}} \text{.}
negative
Water is flowing out of the tank, so the volume of water will decrease over time. The net change in
V
over the first
5\text{ hours}
is expected to be negative to indicate the volume has decreased.
0
If the net change in
V
was
0,
then there would be exactly the same volume of water in the tank at the end of the
5\text{ hours}
as was in the tank at the start. Water is flowing out of the tank (and no additional water is being added into the tank), so the expectation is that there will be less water in the tank after
5\text{ hours,}
not the same amount of water.
positive
If the net change in
V
was positive, then there would be more water in the tank at the end of the
5\text{ hours}
than in the tank at the start. Water is flowing out of the tank (and no additional water is being added into the tank), so the expectation is that there will be less water in the tank after

Lesson summary
Measuring the rate of change of a volume can be easier than measuring the volume itself. Ex: Measuring a flow rate with a flow meter is easier than measuring the volume of water.
The Net Change Theorem can be used to integrate the rate of change of a volume to find the net change in volume.
We can also integrate the rate of change of an area to find the net change in area.
Additional applications using net change
In many real-world situations we know how fast a quantity is changing but don't know the function itself. Luckily, we can find the net change by integrating the rate of change.
In economics, marginal functions are used to describe how quantities change with each additional unit produced or sold:
Marginal cost
C^\prime(x)\text{:}
the cost of producing one more unit.
Marginal revenue
R^\prime(x)\text{:}
the revenue from selling one more unit.
Marginal profit
P^\prime(x)\text{:}
the profit from producing and selling one more unit.
The net change in cost, revenue, or profit can be found by integrating these marginal functions.
Ex: A shipping company finds that the base shipping cost is
\$3
per box, and each additional box costs a bit more to ship. The company's marginal cost function for shipping
x\text{ boxes per day}
is
C^\prime(x) = 3 + x \text{.}
We can use this information to find the change in cost when increasing shipments from
4
to
8\text{ boxes per day.}
This lesson will explore this example and additional applications that use the Net Change Theorem.

Lesson summary
In many real-world situations, an integral of a rate of change can be used to find the net change.
In economics, marginal functions are used to determine if increasing production will be profitable. Use the Net Change Theorem to integrate a marginal function and find the net change in the corresponding function.
In biology, populations are frequently described by growth rates. Use the Net Change Theorem to integrate the growth rate and find the net change in population size.
Net Change Theorem

P

is
\underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}} \text{.}
By the Net Change Theorem, the net change in population size
P
over
[0, #b#]
is
\begin{align*} P(#b#) - P(0) & = \displaystyle \int_{0}^{#b#} P^\prime(t) \, dt && \text{Net change} \\& = \displaystyle \int_{0}^{#b#} (\ln (#r#))#r#^t \, dt && \text{Substitute} \\ & = (\ln (#r#)) \displaystyle \int_{0}^{#b#} #r#^t \, dt && \text{Constant multiple} \\& = (\ln (#r#))\left( \frac{1}{\ln (#r#)} #r#^t \right) {\Large|}_{0}^{#b#} && \text{Integrate} \\ & = \left( #r#^t \right) {\Large|}_{0}^{#b#} && \text{Simplify} \\ & = \left( #r#^{#b#} \right) - \left( #r#^{0} \right) && \text{Substitute}  \\ & = \left( #r#^{#b#} \right) - 1 && \text{Simplify}  \\ & = #ans# \text{ rabbits} && \text{Combine} \\\end{align*}
